Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 45269-001 
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
Cook Islands: Implementing Public Sector Reforms 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of the Cook Islands and its agencies 
ends on 30 June. FY before a calendar year denotes the year in which the fiscal

(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars, unless otherwise stated. 
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  R. Wihtol, Pacific Department (PARD) 
Director  A. Ruthenberg, Pacific Subregional Office, PARD

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The focus of the capacity development technical assistance (TA) project is consistent 
with the aims of Te Kaveinga Nui, the Cook Islands' National Sustainable Development Plan 
(NSDP), 2007–2010,1 and ADB’s Pacific Approach 2010–2014.2 The TA follows on from policy 
advisory TA to support public finance management and public sector performance review.3 It will 
implement  priority  public  sector  reforms  recommended  by  the  functional  review  conducted 
under the earlier TA and endorsed by the Government of the Cook Islands.  
 
2.  A fact-finding mission for the TA4 visited the Cook Islands on 22–30 August 2011 and 
reached an understanding with the government and other stakeholders on the impact, outcome, 
outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for 
consulting services. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.   
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  There had been no review of the Cook Islands public service since the major public 
sector reforms in 1995–1996 that were driven by a financial crisis rooted in an expanding public 
sector, limited resource base, and accelerating debt burden. The reforms reduced the number 
of ministries by about one-third, and the number of civil servants from 3,200 in 1995 to 1,868 in 
1996. That effort and other reforms resulted in average gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 
6% per annum from 1999 to 2004. However, minimal infrastructure investment, the impact of 
several cyclones, high inflation, and the global economic crisis led to an economic contraction in 
the latter part of the decade. The economy is gradually recovering with growth of 0.5% in 2010, 
estimated growth of 1.1% in FY2011, and expectations of higher growth over the medium term. 
The government recognized that another public sector reform program will be essential for 
boosting  economic  management  to  maintain  growth.  This  will  go  hand  in  hand  with  the 
commitment to the updated financial ratios: (i) tax revenue not to exceed 25% of GDP unless it 
is due to better compliance and efficiency; (ii) public sector wages and salaries not to exceed  
44% of total revenue and to be reduced to 40% in the out years; (iii) debt servicing not to 
exceed 5% of total revenue; (iv) overall deficit not to exceed 2% of GDP; and (v) net debt not to 
exceed 35% of GDP. 
 
4.  The number of civil servants has averaged about 1,750 since the mid-2000s. Despite 
this, the public service as a proportion of the workforce grew from 16% in 1996 to 18% in 2006. 
The ratio of population per public sector employee decreased from 9.7 in 1996 to 7.4 in 2006 as 
the population declined due to out-migration. Meanwhile, it was noted that the budget had 
tripled since the reforms with no corresponding improvement in the quality of service delivery. 
The assessment of the public service was initiated by the previous government and endorsed 
by the current government when it assumed office in November 2010, signaling high-level 
commitment to the reforms. While the earlier reforms were driven by a financial crisis, the 
current ones are focused on strengthening leadership; stronger performance based on clear 
output requirements; greater efficiency; empowerment of the outer islands; and public–private 
partnerships.  
 
                                                 
1  Government of the Cook Islands. 2007. Te Kaveinga Nui – National Sustainable Development Plan, 2007–2010. 
Rarotonga. A new NSDP (2011–2014) will be launched in early 2012. 
2  ADB. 2009. ADB’s Pacific Approach 2010–2014. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the Cook Islands for the Public Finance Management and Public Sector 
Review. Manila (TA 7646-COO, approved in November 2010). 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 30 November 2011.

2  
5.  The functional review of the public service raised a number of issues: (i) structures and 
priorities are not aligned with the NSDP; (ii) the quality of services is suboptimal; (iii) there is a 
lack  of  separation  in  policy,  regulation,  and  service  provision;  (iv)  business  plans  and 
performance  management  systems  are  generally  of  poor  quality;  (v)  there  is  a  need  to 
strengthen the leadership and performance management role of the Office of the Public Service 
Commission (OPSC); (vi) outer island mayors and councils feel disempowered by the current 
roles  and  structures;  (vii)  state-owned  enterprises  lack  accountability  and  show  poor 
performance; (viii) complementary functions and agencies need to be grouped into sectors; and 
(ix) some functions are fragmented across more than one ministry.  
 
6.  The review proposed the following actions: to (i) shift to a medium-term, outcome-
oriented  budgeting  framework;  (ii)  organize  and  empower  outer  islands'  governance; 
(iii) strengthen administration systems through shared non-core services; (iv) organize ministries 
and crown agencies into eight sectors; (v) strengthen public–private partnerships; (vi) provide a 
more cohesive approach to economic development; (vii) redefine constitutional agencies; and 
(viii) strengthen the OPSC. As regards the restructuring into eight sectors, the government has 
indicated a two-stage implementation, reflecting capacity constraints in the public service. The 
government  has  articulated  its  reform  priorities  based  on  (i)  the  need  to  protect  people's 
livelihoods; (ii) a clear identification of benefits from the change; (iii) a change process that is 
measured and managed (“sure and steadfast”) with a defined communications strategy to 
ensure engagement of all stakeholders; and (iv) an initial focus on changes that are easier to 
introduce, leaving the more difficult changes for consideration later in the process. Based on 
this,  the  structural  changes  in  selected  newly  defined  sectors  (to  be  confirmed  by  the 
government by end December 2011) will be implemented in stage 1 with support from this TA, 
to be effective in FY2013. The process of reforming the other remaining sectors will begin under 
this TA but be completed in stage 2, proposed to be supported by follow-on ADB capacity 
development TA in the country operations business plan pipeline for 2013 approval. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The expected impact of the TA will be sound economic management of the Cook Islands 
economy to maintain a targeted annual economic growth rate of at least 3.5% over the medium 
term. The expected TA outcome will be a more responsive and cost-effective scope, structure, 
and size of selected public service sectors, aligned with national priorities. The new structure of 
the selected sectors will become effective on 1 July 2012, with necessary resources reflected in 
the FY2013 national budget.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will support the government in implementing (i) the functional and organizational 
structures of selected public service sectors to be confirmed by the government by the end of 
December 2011, (ii) changes to outer island administration, and (iii) an effective public service 
policies manual. 
 
9.  Output  1:  Restructuring  of  the  Cook  Islands  public  service  (stage  1).  Before 
effecting changes to the existing sectors and line ministries, several actions are essential. The 
government, at its highest level, has taken ownership of this process and will appoint a minister 
to oversee implementation along with a steering committee, supported by a project manager 
and the TA team. Necessary legislative amendments will be drafted for approval in line with

3
endorsed core functions and approved organizational structures. The heads and second-tier 
managers of the restructured ministries (corresponding to the selected sectors) will also be 
appointed and, along with the OPSC and the TA team, will develop the business plans complete 
with  staff  requirements  by  function  and  grading  (including  job  descriptions),  logistics,  and 
funding requirements, which also informs the budget process. The TA team will help develop 
strategies  that  enable  appropriate  management  of  surplus  positions  identified  through  the 
restructuring process. Once ministries are fully staffed, the TA will support them in preparing 
their service charters. Awareness programs and capacity development will be an ongoing part 
of the implementation.  
 
10.  Output 2: Changes to the Cook Islands outer island administration. The review 
recommended that responsibility for outer island administration be under the auspices of the 
local government division to be established in the Office of the Prime Minister. Once the director 
of local government is appointed, a rollout plan for outer island empowerment, including relevant 
memorandums of understanding with the different island councils, will be finalized. Awareness 
programs and capacity development will again be a crucial and ongoing part of implementation. 
 
11.  Output 3: Effective public service policies manual. The functional review team of the 
earlier  TA,  led  by  the  governance  analyst  and  counterpart  staff,  paved  the  way  for  the 
preparation of the public service policies manual. The OPSC will finalize the manual, including 
guidelines for issues likely to arise from implementing the new structures. The TA will continue 
to assist this process and support development of reporting lines to monitor effectiveness of the 
manual. The TA will support development of a citizen's report card tied to service charters to 
gauge public feedback on service delivery. 
 
12.  There are always risks associated with public sector reforms. Such changes can be 
politically sensitive and the 1995–1996 experience means that the public’s confidence in the 
benefit of such reforms is very low. More broadly, there is a risk that potential job losses will 
lead to more out-migration given the easy accessibility for Cook Islanders of New Zealand and 
Australia. It is critical that the current reform momentum is maintained, hence there should be a 
seamless implementation process. In selecting the sectors for stage 1 implementation, the 
government will focus on positive changes that are easier to introduce and will gain the public’s 
confidence. A good communications strategy and awareness program will also help clarify 
issues and promote the benefits while alleviating fears of change. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at the equivalent of $625,000. The government has 
requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, transport and other 
in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The OPSC will be the executing and implementing agency for the TA. The government 
will  appoint  a  minister  to  oversee  implementation  of  the  reforms  along  with  the  steering 
committee already established under the earlier TA.  
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 16 months from 1 January 2012 to 30 April 2013. The 
TA is expected to finance 16 person-months of intermittent international consulting inputs and

4  
24 person-months of national consulting inputs. The consultants will work as a cohesive team to 
deliver  the  tasks  as  outlined  in  the  terms  of  reference  in  Appendix  3.  The  international 
consulting team will comprise a project management and public sector reform specialist, who 
will be team leader (8 person-months); a human resource management and organizational 
change specialist (4 person-months); and a legal review  specialist (4 person-months). The 
national consulting team will consist of a local government reform advisor (12 person-months) 
and a public sector reform advisor (12 person-months). 
 
16.  The consultants will be selected and engaged on an individual basis and according to 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Preliminary 
cost estimates are in Appendix 2. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Equipment will be purchased in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as 
amended from time to time) and will be turned over to the executing agency upon completion of 
TA activities. 
17.  The team leader will produce a concise inception report outlining the work program and 
milestones for the duration of the TA, and a final report summarizing the achievements, issues, 
lessons learned, and next steps. Throughout the TA, the team leader will submit (by e-mail) 
brief monthly progress reports summarizing TA activities, progress, issues, and constraints. 
Team members will produce inputs (reports on their activities) for the team leader's progress 
and final reports. The team leader's final report will be submitted in draft form at least 5 weeks 
before the end of the assignment, and the final version within 2 weeks of receiving comments 
from the government and ADB. 
 
18.  Progress of the TA will be monitored on the basis of intended outcomes and outputs 
described in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). ADB will assist the government 
in  sharing  all  reports  with  key  development  partners,  and  in  disseminating  them  through 
roundtable meetings, radio interviews, and the ADB website.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Cook Islands for Implementing Public Sector Reforms, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The capacity development technical assistance (TA) project of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) will support the implementation of priority public service reforms recommended by 
the functional review of an earlier TA and endorsed by the Government of the Cook Islands. 
This TA will (i) support the implementation of new functional and organizational public service 
structures in four sectors, (ii) support the implementation of the new outer island administration 
structure, and (iii) assist the finalization of an effective public service policies and procedures 
manual. The TA will require the following consulting services: 
 
2.  Project  management  and  public  sector  reform  specialist  and  team  leader 
(international, 8 person-months intermittent). The specialist will have a strong background in the 
implementation of public sector reforms and organizational development. The consultant should 
have at least 10 years of experience, preferably in the Pacific region, and should hold a tertiary 
degree, preferably a master’s degree in public sector management and finance, or a related 
field. The consultant should have excellent communication skills, both written and verbal, and 
be skilled in the use of consultative and participatory processes. 
 
3.  Detailed tasks include: 
 
(i)  support the preparation of a time-bound implementation plan for rollout of public 
service reforms endorsed by the government and based on recommendations of 
the functional review, and including a monitoring and evaluation framework; 
(ii)  support preparation of new or revised job descriptions for a new functional and 
organizational structure; 
(iii)  support  the  director  of  local  government  in  preparing  a  time-bound 
implementation plan for rollout of the new outer island administration structure, 
including a monitoring and evaluation framework; 
(iv)  support implementation of a coordinated planning and monitoring process in line 
with the fiscal year 2013 budget process, incorporating the new organizational 
structure of the public service; 
(v)  assist  in  the  recruitment  of  new  heads  of  ministries  and  the  next  layer  of 
management; 
(vi)  support a review of the public service remuneration system; 
(vii)  support the government in preparing transitional arrangements for “surplus” staff; 
(viii)  assist operationalization of the public service policies and procedures manual, 
including  development  of  reporting  lines  between  line  ministries  and  central 
agencies to monitor implementation of the manual; 
(ix)  liaise with the working group and steering committee to discuss draft reports and 
submission as per TA milestones; 
(x)  conduct  information  gathering,  presentation  workshops,  and  awareness 
programs with public service personnel and other stakeholders; 
(xi)  manage the TA team and liaise with the Office of the Public Service Commission 
(OPSC) and other key stakeholders throughout the duration of the TA; 
(xii)  administer  TA  training  and  equipment  budgets  in  accordance  with  ADB 
guidelines; and 
(xiii)  prepare project-related reports, i.e., an inception report with a TA work program, 
regular status reports, a draft final report, and a final report.

Appendix 3  9 
4.  Human resource management and organizational change specialist (international, 4 
person-months intermittent). The specialist will have a background appropriate to the tasks set 
out below, with at least 10 years of experience in public administration and organizational 
change, and significant experience relevant to small island states, and should hold a tertiary 
degree in public administration or finance. 
5.   Detailed tasks include: 
 
(i)  support  the  OPSC  in  preparing  a  human  resource  management  system 
applicable to all ministries of government; 
(ii)  support the preparation of a communications strategy and awareness program 
for rollout of the implementation plans; 
(iii)  support the OPSC and line ministries in the conduct of an awareness program 
explaining the proposed changes; 
(iv)  support the preparation of and conduct a capacity development program to ease 
implementation  of  the  proposed  reforms  and  new  structures  for  both  line 
ministries and outer islands; 
(vi)  assist  central  agencies,  line  ministries,  and  outer  island  administrations  in 
preparing service charters to reflect their new functions; 
(vii)  assist the OPSC and other government agencies in preparing a citizen's report 
card to gauge public feedback on service delivery; and 
(viii)  contribute to project reporting as needed. 
 
6.  Legal review specialist (international, 4 person-months). The specialist must have a 
tertiary qualification in law and a background in the practice of law with a minimum of 10 years 
of post-qualification experience. The specialist must have extensive experience in legislative 
drafting, preferably in developing countries and the Pacific. 
7.   Detailed tasks include: 
 
(i)  using  the  review  of  legislations  conducted  as  part  of  the  functional  review, 
determine  necessary  legislative  amendments  that  render  the  new  functional 
structures of the public service effective; 
(ii)  draft the required legislative amendments in consultation with key stakeholders; 
(iii)  conduct necessary meetings with the steering committee and the Office of the 
Solicitor-General to finalize draft laws and amendments; 
(iv)  conduct  necessary  consultations  with  key  stakeholders  on  draft  laws  and 
amendments; 
(v)  review  feedback  from  consultations  and  incorporate  into  final  laws  and 
amendments; 
(vi)  present final laws and amendments to the Office of the Solicitor-General for 
advancing through the legislative approval process; and 
(vii)  contribute to project reporting as needed.  
 
8.  Local  government  reform  advisor  (national,  12  person-months  intermittent).  The 
advisor must have a minimum of 5 years of relevant work experience in areas related to local 
government reform and the implementation of change, preferably in the Cook Islands. The 
advisor must have experience in working in teams and in capacity building, and have good 
communication skills in both English and Cook Islands Te Reo Maori.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
9.  Detailed tasks include:  
 
(i)  support the team leader and the director of local government in developing the 
implementation plan for the new outer island administration structure; 
(ii)  support the development of terms of reference for local government Clerk of 
Council and Government representatives; 
(iii)  assist the director of local government in preparing a plan on how to empower 
local communities in the outer islands, including a capacity development plan to 
carry out their new roles; 
(iv)  help the director of local government develop memorandum of understanding 
with  recentralized  agencies  and  reporting  processes  between  the  the  outer 
islands and the central government; 
(v)  support the organizational change specialist in delivering capacity development 
of the director of local government on managing and providing services to the 
outer island communities; and 
(vi)  contribute to project reporting a needed. 
  
10.  Public sector reform advisor (national, 12 person-months intermittent). The advisor 
must have at least 5 years of work experience in areas related to public sector reform and the 
implementation of reform programs. The advisor must have experience working in a team and 
good communication skills in both English and Cook Islands Te Reo Maori. 
 
11.  Detailed tasks include:  
 
(i)  assist the team leader and TA team in the implementation of the public service 
reforms; 
(ii)  support the implementation of the coordinated planning and monitoring process; 
in  particular,  define  links  with  the  National  Sustainable  Development  Plan, 
business plans, and the budget process; 
(iii)  assist the legal specialist in determining the need for legislative amendments 
based on the assessment undertaken as part of the functional review; 
(iv)  help finalize the public service policies and procedures manual, and help conduct 
an awareness program on policies and procedures, and their implementation; 
(v)  assist  in  monitoring  the  manual’s  implementation  progress,  pointing  out 
bottlenecks and issues and making recommendations on how to resolve those; 
(vi)  help monitor the progress of public service reforms using the monitoring and 
evaluation framework; and 
(vii)  contribute to project reporting as needed. 
 
12.  Reporting requirements. The team leader will prepare an inception report for ADB and 
the government within 8 weeks of the start of field activities. It will include a time-bound TA work 
plan. Monthly progress reports will be submitted throughout the TA, and a draft final report will 
be completed 5 weeks prior to the end of the assignment. The final report is to be submitted 
within 2 weeks of receiving government and ADB comments on the draft final report.
